ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained great perspective into the world of art history and contemporary art. Professor Campbell covered the basics as well as some of the preliminary social theory that once I learned about it, wondered how I could have gone on without knowing about it. The Biennale is also one of those things only the wealthy usually really get to encountersomething worth considering.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Campbell is a brilliant lecturer, and obviously possesses such a great breadth and depth of knowledge in the art world that it truly feels insane to engage with her. However, the syllabus wasn't available for the first month or so of classes, and when it was it was inaccurate so you would have to listen to what she said was the reading at the end of the class to know what it was. Sometimes this still wouldn't be accurate. Oftentimes the readings were available at the Haas library, which was incredibly inconvenient and inaccessible. It wasn't conducive at all for a seminar style, reading based course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I wouldn't. Lack of clarity on assignments and reading made the semester one big guessing game that was at best anxiety inducing and at worst an incredibly poor pedagogy.
